Graphical abstract An innovative strategy to in-situ grow bimetallic phosphide heterostructure nanowire arrays with lattice-torsion interfaces for solar-driven water splitting with 19.8% STH efficiency has been proposed. Designing cost-effective and high-efficiency electrocatalysts is critical to the water splitting performance during hydrogen generation. Herein, we have developed Fe2P-Co2P heterostructure nanowire arrays with excellent lattice torsions and grain boundaries for highly efficient water splitting. According to the microstructural investigations and theoretical calculations, the lattice torsion interface not only contributes to the exposure of more active sites but also effectively tunes the adsorption energy of hydrogen/oxygen intermediates via the accumulation of charge redistribution. As a result, the Fe2P-Co2P heterostructure nanowire array exhibits exceptional bifunctional catalytic activity with overpotentials of 65 and 198 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions, respectively. Moreover, the Fe2P-Co2P/NF-assembled electrolyzer can deliver 10 mA cm−2 at an ultralow voltage of 1.51 V while resulting in a high solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency of 19.8% in the solar-driven water electrolysis cell. Keywords Transition metal phosphide Lattice torsion Heterogeneous interfaces Water splitting Theoretical calculation 1 Introduction Electrocatalytic water splitting is one of the intriguing frontiers for producing clean and sustainable hydrogen. It could tackle the existing serious problems in energy production and environmental concerns [1–6]. However, the sluggish two-electron transfer processes (hydrogen evolution reaction, HER) and four proton-transfer process (oxygen evolution reaction, OER) on the surface of the electrode remain the main obstacles to large-scale electrocatalytic hydrogen production [7–10]. The high-efficiency Pt-based and Ru/Ir-based catalysts are regarded as the benchmark electrocatalysts for HER and OER, respectively. However, they suffer from exorbitant prices and a lack of supply [11–13]. The newly developed electrocatalysts are the subject of intense research. Among them, the transition metals and their compounds can work as a class of ideal bifunctional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting [14–18]. Because of the collective effect of metal nanoclusters chemically integrated into a P lattice in transition metal phosphides (TMPs), the phosphorus and metal sites serve as proton acceptor and hydride acceptor sites, respectively [19]. Unfortunately, fundamental obstacles such as slow kinetics and poor long-term stability continue to obstruct the possibility of attaining industrialization [20,21]. Therefore, it is necessary to conduct further research to develop low-cost and high-performance transition metal electrocatalysts while understanding the root cause of overall water splitting application [1,22–24]. Currently, various modification approaches, including valence state regulation, defect engineering, strain engineering, and hetero doping effects, have been proposed to enhance the corrosion resistance and unlock another potential of TMPs [25–27]. Numerous studies have shown that the heterogeneous bimetallic phosphides, including FeP/Ni2P, Ni2P-Fe2P, and Ni2P-Co2P, have the advantage in overall water splitting due to their structural characteristics and electron configurations [28,29]. Based on the interactions between catalytic active sites and intermediate species, high-performance TMPs catalysts favor HER in alkaline media despite having a more challenging Volmer step than in acid. The metal oxides/(oxy)hydroxides formed during the in situ reconstructions of TMPs are considered the real active species for OER in comparison to the corresponding directly synthesized original catalysts [30]. Owing to the superior active sites and exposed crystal facets, the integration of hetero-nanophases into cobalt-based catalysts enables them to modulate the surface electronic distribution and induce synergistic effects among different components, which results in an exceptional performance from the rational construction of heterostructures [31–33]. Under strong oxidizing conditions, the catalysts get covered by a heterogeneous surface, resulting in excellent physicochemical properties compared to the parent phase(s) [34]. On the other hand, it has been recently reported that the grain boundaries and stacking faults from the lattice torsion boost the catalytic activity while maintaining catalytic stability [35]. Therefore, a thorough comprehension of the derived surface and identification of the heterostructures is vital to understanding the catalytic origin and the key to logically designing the water-splitting reaction [36,37]. However, the integrated heterostructure with excellent HER/OER activities and durability still faces an enormous challenge in the commercial large-scale water splitting application. Herein, a novel Fe2P-Co2P heterostructure nanowire array on nickel foam (Fe2P-Co2P/NF) was successfully synthesized via a facile hydrothermal reaction followed by a low-temperature phosphorization process. The heterostructure was comprised of a crystalline Fe2P phase integrated into a Co2P matrix, that required only 65 and 198 mV overpotentials to afford the current density of 10 mA cm−2 for the HER and OER, respectively. Due to the abundant grain boundaries induced by lattice torsion and in-situ OER active species, a strong charge concentration at the interfacial regions between Fe2P and Co2P was accumulated. The accumulated charge resulted in a lower activation energy barrier of the HER/OER intermediates and enhanced water splitting activity. Furthermore, the solar-driven water electrolysis cell delivered a high and stable solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency (19.8%). This work provides new insights into developing efficient electrocatalysts by using lattice-torsion interface engineering strategies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Pretreatment of nickel foam The nickel foam (2 cm × 3 cm) was firstly cleaned with acetone, water, and ethanol by ultrasonic treatment for 10 min, respectively. After that, the nickel foam was cleaned in a 3 M HCl solution for 15 min, followed by sonication sequentially in water and ethanol several times. The NF was taken out and washed with water and ethanol thoroughly before being vacuum dried. 2.2 Synthesis of Co-Fe nanowires arrays precursor (Co-Fe NWAs precursor/NF) In a typical synthetic method, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Fe(NO3)3·6H2O, urea (6 mmol), and NH4F (2.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of H2O and EG (H2O:EG = 2:1) for 30 minutes while vigorously stirring. The integral molar quantity of Fe and Co is 1 mmol, and the Fe content is 0, 10%, 20%, and 30%, respectively. Then the solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave. A piece of nickel foam was immersed in the reaction solution. The autoclave was sealed and kept at 120 °C for 10 hours, with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1. When the temperature returned to room temperature, the obtained Co-Fe NWAs precursor/NF was cleaned with water and ethanol several times and dried at 60 °C overnight in a vacuum drying oven. 2.3 Synthesis of Fe2P-Co2P nanowires arrays (Fe2P-Co2P/NF) The Fe2P-Co2P/NF electrode was fabricated through a facile phosphorization treatment. In brief, 500 mg of NaH2PO2·H2O and a pre-prepared Co-Fe NWAs precursor/NF were placed on the upstream side and center of the tube furnace, respectively. The sample was then calcined at 350 °C for 2 h in an Ar atmosphere with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1. Finally, the Fe2P-Co2P/NF was obtained after cooling down to room temperature. The loading of Fe2P-Co2P/NF nanowire arrays on nickel foam is about 2.5 mg cm−2. The Co2P/NF was synthesized using Co NWAs precursor/NF as a precursor under a similar method. These values are roughly consistent from batch to batch using this synthetic procedure. The synthesis of electrode of Pt/C and RuO2 on nickel foam, electrochemical measurements, materials characterizations, and the DFT calculation method are described in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structural characterizations The Fe2P-Co2P/NF electrocatalyst was obtained by a two-step process (Fig. 1 a). The Co-Fe hydroxide precursor was first grown uniformly on nickel foam according to our previous procedure (Fig. S1). Subsequently, the Fe2P-Co2P/NF heterostructure was obtained via a low-temperature phosphorization at 350 °C for 2 h. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) image illustrated the presence of numerous nanowires, uniformly and vertically assembled on the nickel foam support. The configuration was favorable for electron transport while offering a broad contact surface [38], similar to the Co-Fe hydroxide precursor which maintained an intact structure after the phosphorization process (Fig. 1b and c). The morphology of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF and Co2P/NF catalysts was also investigated under different molar ratios [x = Fe/(Fe + Co)], where x = 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 (Fig. S2). The transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to investigate the microstructures of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF under the molar ratio [Fe/(Fe + Co)] of 0.2. It further illustrated the presence of well-dispersed nanoparticle-decorated nanowires with a diameter of 50 nm (Fig. 1d and Fig. S3a). A merged linear structure of the stacking of granulum and rich lattice torsions and grain boundaries uniformly dispersed in Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Fig. 1e), could trigger abundant active sites and heterogeneous interfaces to boost the electrocatalytic activity [39]. The HRTEM image clearly indicated the presence of constructed heterostructure nanowire and abundant lattice torsion interfaces. The interfacial region between the two constituents was highlighted in Fig. 1(f) and further magnified in Fig. 1(g), where a crystalline lattice spacing of 0.220 nm was attributed to the (210) crystal facet of the Co2P structure. Another lattice fringe of 0.192 nm was appropriately indexed to the (210) crystal facet in the Fe2P structure. It was evident that Co2P (210) and Fe2P (210) had a close contact relationship. This unique contact structure can offer abundant grain boundaries and more active sites while enhancing the inherent catalytic performance [29,40]. The HAADF-STEM image and corresponding EDS analysis indicated that the Fe, Co, and P elements were uniformly distributed over the whole heterostructure nanowire of Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Fig. 1h and Fig. S3). The release of H2 and O2 was accelerated by interconnected heterostructure nanowire arrays having abundant active sites for electrochemical reactions. Moreover, the multidimensional electron transport pathways also made it easier for the electrolyte to penetrate. In the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (Fig. 2 a and Fig. S4), the diffraction peaks could be ascribed to Fe2P (JCPDS no. 51–0943), Co2P (JCPDS no. 32–0306) and Ni (JCPDS no. 04–0850). Furthermore, all of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF catalysts with different molar ratios [Fe/(Fe + Co)] indicated the presence of the same diffraction peaks while implying that the heterostructural compositions were successfully produced after the corresponding thermal phosphorization (Fig. S5). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) confirmed the presence of Fe, Co, P, O, and C elements in Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Fig. 2b and Fig. S6). As depicted in Fig. 2(c), the contribution to Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 electronic states was detected at 711.6 and 725.8 eV, indicating the presence of Fe2+ [41,42]. The minor component located at around 715.3 eV was associated with the Fe oxide species (Fe-O) induced by the inevitable surface oxidation of Fe2P. Furthermore, the peak at 707.4 eV was attributed to the Fe δ + (0 < δ < 2) in Fe2P, which was found to be active for HER [43]. In addition, Co 2p 3/2 (778.5 eV) and Co 2p 1/2 (793.5 eV) peaks were assigned to Co δ + (0 < δ < 2) in Co2P (Fig. 2d). The Co-O species can be divided into Co 2p spectra from the unavoidable surface oxidation [44,45]. Moreover, Co 2p peaks of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF shifted by 0.4 eV to a lower binding energy than pure Co2P/NF, indicating that the incorporation of Fe atoms could effectively increase the electron density of Co2P and significantly accelerate electron carrier transfer pathway via the modulated electronic structure of Co atoms and result in unsaturated Co δ+ [46]. For P 2p orbitals, the peaks around 129.4 and 130.3 eV were associated with P 2p 3/2 and P 2p 1/2 of the metal-P bonding (Fig. 2e) and the peak at 133.5 eV was assigned to oxidized phosphorus species (ex: PO4 3−) [47]. Similarly, an apparent negative shift of the P 2p peak was guided by the Fe atom, indicating the strong electronic interactions between Co2P and Fe2P. The peaks at 531.8 and 532.9 eV were ascribed to the M−OH (M = Co, Fe) and the surface-adsorbed H2O molecules, in the O 1s region, respectively (Fig. 2f). The solid-liquid contact interface between catalysts and electrolytes is crucial in water splitting catalysis [30]. The water droplets were swiftly absorbed by the super-hydrophilic Fe2P-Co2P/NF, whereas they were easily attached to the bare NF, resulting in a decline in water splitting performance (Fig. 2g and h). Fig. 2(i) depicted that water droplets adhered to the surface of bare NF and Fe2P-Co2P/NF owing to the decline in contact interface. Therefore, the electrolyte transfer was hindered. However, the Fe2P-Co2P/NF nanowire array structure could lead to the rapid absorption of the water droplets to maintain the original active sites. The combined analysis demonstrated that the heterostructure between Co2P and Fe2P catalysts was successfully constructed, resulting in a unique electronic structural effect that improved the electrocatalytic activity of the HER/OER. 3.2 Electrochemical performance of Fe2P-Co2P/NF The HER activity of Fe2P-Co2P/NF was initially examined in a 1 M KOH electrolyte to confirm the synergistic enhancement effect of heterostructures. As shown in Fig. 3 (a and c), Fe2P-Co2P/NF demonstrates excellent HER performance with ultralow overpotentials of 65, 130, and 156 mV to reach current densities of 10, 100, and 200 mA cm−2, respectively. It was found to be superior to the bare NF, Co2P/NF and the commercial Pt/C catalysts (a current density of >83 mA cm−2). The Tafel slope of Fe2P-Co2P/NF was found to be small (44.4 mV dec−1) compared to bare NF (164.8 mV dec−1) and Co2P/NF (72.6 mV dec−1) (Fig. 3b). Such a low value approaches the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C (37.5 mV dec−1), indicating its Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism and accelerated HER kinetics [48,49]. This performance was superior to most of the previously reported HER electrocatalysts (Table S3). The smaller charge transfer resistance indicated the presence of an accelerated charge transport process (Fig. 3d). The ECSA was estimated using the double-layer capacitance (C dl) to understand the inherent and extraordinary activity of the catalyst. As depicted in Fig. 3(e), the Fe2P-Co2P/NF had a higher C dl value (87.24 mF cm−2) compared to the Co2P/NF (30.53 mF cm−2) and bare NF (2.78 mF cm−2). The ECSA-normalized LSV curves were carried out to interpret the intrinsic activities of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Fig. S12a). The high HER performance was attributed to the unique interfacial interaction and synergetic catalytic effect induced by the heterointerface and the active sites generated by the substrate [45,50]. In addition, the Fe2P-Co2P/NF had a higher turnover frequency (TOF) than Co2P/NF due to its increased electrochemical activity (Fig. S13a). The polarization curve was repeated up to 5000 cycles to further investigate the stability of Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Fig. 3f). Meanwhile, there was no obvious change in the current density at 20 mA cm−2 while being subjected to continuous tests over 100 h (inset of Fig. 3f), suggesting exceptional HER stability. Moreover, the morphology and structure of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF were effectively retained, as confirmed by the post-SEM, TEM, and XRD measurements (Figs. S15–S17). The long-term stability of Fe2P-Co2P/NF nanowire arrays for HER was further evaluated by the post-XPS analysis. The notable elements such as Fe 2p, Co 2p, P 2p, and O 1s and the expected functionalities are observed as before, which confirms that the leaching of metal ions was very low and showed excellent long-term stability of the catalyst even after HER (Fig. S18). In addition to the outstanding HER activities, Fe2P-Co2P/NF also exhibits superior OER activities with overpotentials of 198, 222, and 236 mV to reach 10, 100, and 200 mA cm−2, respectively, which. were smaller than those of Co2P/NF (232, 283, and 311 mV) and RuO2 (280, 352, and 395 mV) at the same current density (Fig. 3g and Fig. S11f). Furthermore, the Tafel slope and charge transfer resistance of Fe2P-Co2P/NF were determined to be only 24.1 mV dec−1 and 3.8 Ω, respectively, which were significantly lower than other electrocatalysts (Table S5). Furthermore, it demonstrated rapid reaction kinetics and excellent charge transfer properties after constructing heterostructures (Fig. 3h and Fig. S11e). Similar to the HER activities, the C dl values of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF were determined to be 82.60 mF cm−2, which was higher than those of Co2P/NF (51.31 mF cm−2) and bare NF (2.45 mF cm−2) (Fig. S11d). It indicated that the Fe2P-Co2P/NF could generate abundant catalytic active sites for OER. Additionally, the ECSA-normalized OER performance and the TOFs value of Fe2P-Co2P/NF were also significantly higher than those of Co2P/NF, highlighting the critical significance of constructed Fe2P-Co2P/NF heterostructures in facilitating the OER intrinsic activity (Figs. S12b and S13b). The polarization curves after 5000 cycles and the chronoamperometry (j-t) measurements exhibited no obvious degradation activity after a long-term operation at 20 mA cm−2 for 100 h. It collectively indicated the outstanding durability of Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Fig. 3i). The morphology and composition of Fe2P-Co2P following the OER process were investigated to better explain the mechanisms of surface reconstruction. The Fe2P-Co2P/NF maintained conformity throughout the OER process, according to SEM and XRD measurements (Figs. S19 and S20a–c). Furthermore, the XPS spectrums of O 1s and P 2p (Fig. S21) and the TEM images further demonstrated the partial surface oxidation of Fe2P-Co2P/NF nanowires (Fig. S20d). Based on the aforementioned results, the exceptional OER performance was ascribed to the synergy of metal-phosphides and out-layer oxyhydroxide heterointerfaces. 3.3 Water splitting activity of Fe2P-Co2P/NF The exceptional performance and stability of Fe2P-Co2P/NF for HER and OER have indicated its potential to be used as cathode and anode in practical water electrolysis. The two-electrode configuration was constructed (Fe2P-Co2P/NF||Fe2P-Co2P/NF). They provided the ultralow cell voltages of 1.51, 1.64, and 1.70 V at 10, 100, and 200 mA cm−2, respectively, in contrast to the commercial Pt/C-RuO2 electrode (1.56, 1.75, and 1.83 V). The overall water splitting performance of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF electrode was significantly higher than that of many other bifunctional catalysts (Fig. 4 a and d and Table S7). Surprisingly, at a constant current density of 20 mA cm−2, the measured H2 and O2 values closely matched the calculated values, demonstrating almost 100% faraday efficiency of the assembled electrolyzer (Fig. 4b and Table S6). Furthermore, this assembled device could be powered by a 1.5 V AA battery while collecting a large number of H2 and O2 gas bubbles from the surface of the cathode/anode (Fig. 4c). In addition, the assembled electrolyzer demonstrated superior durability in long-term operation with no obvious performance decay while operating for 100 h at 50 mA cm−2 and 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4e). A solar-driven water splitting device based on a multi-junction GaAs solar cell was also assembled as an energy source (Fig. 4f). The J-V curves demonstrated a high STH conversion efficiency (19.8%) and excellent photostability (Fig. 4g and h). After 100 h of continuous operation under AM 1.5G (100 mW cm−2) light, the integrated system demonstrated superior durability with no obvious degradation (Fig. 4i). Therefore, it asserted the promising prospects of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF-based solar-driven water-splitting system. 3.4 Theoretical calculation analysis of Fe2P-Co2P/NF Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to obtain a thorough knowledge of the activities and reaction mechanisms of Fe2P-Co2P/NF. The electronic interaction between the two components was first revealed by examining the difference in charge density plot of Fe2P-Co2P. The original structure models of Fe2P/NF, Co2P/NF and Fe2P-Co2P/NF were presented in Fig. S22. As shown in Fig. 5 (a–c), the substantial accumulation of charge at the Fe2P and Co2P interfacial regions, indicated the presence of a strong charge concentration on the surface of Fe2P-Co2P hetero-interface. Moreover, the remarkable increase in the electronic states of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF near the Fermi level revealed the substantial increase in the interfacial electrical conductivity during water splitting processes of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF electrode, which was consistent with the charge transfer resistance results. Furthermore, the electronic structure of Fe2P-Co2P/NF could be regulated in comparison to pristine Fe2P/NF and Co2P/NF, with the d-band centers of Fe and Co atoms moving to a positive position compared to the Fermi level (Fig. 5d). It is favorable to enhance the electrocatalytic activity of Fe2P-Co2P/NF, which equates to strengthening the adsorption interactions between the intermediates and the surface of Fe2P-Co2P/NF [51,52]. The HER in alkaline solution consists of the H2O adsorption and desorption progress, the formation of the adsorbed intermediate H* and the final release of H2. The optimal adsorption configurations of the H2O molecule on the electrocatalyst surface were depicted in Fig. S24. As shown in Fig. 5(e), the Fe2P-Co2P/NF had substantially higher negative H2O adsorption energy (Co sits, −1.75 eV; Fe site, −1.22 eV) compared to Co2P/NF (−0.68 eV) and Fe2P/NF (−0.45 eV), indicating a more effective H2O adsorption on the Fe2P-Co2P/NF catalyst surface, especially at the interfacial regions. The Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) was also calculated (Fig. S25). As presented in Fig. 5(f) and Table S1, the ΔG H* values of Fe2P/NF, Co2P/NF and Fe2P-Co2P/NF were determined to be −0.499, 0.361, −0.413, 0.330, −0.219, −0.161 and 0.240 eV, respectively. The |ΔG H*| value of Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Co sites, 0.161 eV) was close to zero, suggesting rapid HER kinetics [53,54]. The synergistic effect between Fe2P and Co2P significantly facilitated the desorption of H* and accumulated strong charge concentration at the Fe2P and Co2P interfacial regions, thereby improving the HER catalytic activity. Similarly, the usual OER process in alkaline media occurs through a four-electron mechanism. Therefore, the Gibbs free energies of all intermediates (*OH, *O, *OOH, and O2) were calculated at different constant potentials [55,56]. On the other hand, the optimized adsorption structures with an ultrathin oxide layer configuration were shown in Figs. S23, S26, and S27 to further demonstrate the influence of partial surface oxidation on the theoretical OER activity. The calculated free energy diagram of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF catalyst was presented in Fig. 5(g). The OO coupling (transition from O* to OOH*) was the adsorption energy rate-determining step (RDS) for pure Fe2P/NF, Co2P/NF and Fe2P-Co2P/NF. The computed ΔG RDS energy for Fe and Co sites on the Fe2P/NF and Co2P/NF surfaces were calculated to be 2.27 and 2.10 eV, respectively. The synergistic effect between Fe2P and Co2P could effectively lower the electron transfer barrier. Moreover, as displayed in Fig. 5(i), the apparent formation of Fe-O-Co bridge bonds can provide moderate O-binding strength. It can also contribute further to the formation of OO coupling during the OER catalytic process of the Fe2P-Co2P/NF heterointerface catalyst while leading to a lower energy activation barrier of the OER intermediates. As a result, the energy change of ΔG RDS for Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Co site) remarkably decreased to 1.65 eV (Table S2). For U = 1.23 V (Fig. 5h), the ΔG RDS for Fe2P-Co2P/NF (Co site, 0.42 eV) was substantially lower than Fe2P/NF (1.04 eV) and Co2P/NF (0.87 eV), exhibiting superior OER catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 5(j and k), Fe2P-Co2P can act as conductive support while providing an effective charge transport pathway to the active Co(Fe)OOH surface layers and significantly promoting OER catalysis. Therefore, the heterointerfaces of metal phosphides and active oxyhydroxides surface layers (Fe2P-Co2P/Co(Fe)OOH) were the true active phases for OER, which was consistent with the experiment results. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have innovatively developed Fe2P-Co2P heterostructure nanowire arrays with abundant lattice torsion-induced grain boundaries as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for water-splitting under an alkaline solution. Due to the synergistic effect and the accumulated charge distribution at the interface of lattice torsion, the Fe2P-Co2P heterostructure electrode exhibited exceptional catalytic activity and long-term stability under 65 and 198 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 for HER and OER, respectively. It was found to be significantly better than the commercial Pt/C and RuO2 catalysts and the state-of-the-art metal phosphide-based catalyst. Moreover, the Fe2P-Co2P/NF electrode could deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an ultralow cell voltage of 1.51 V with almost 100% Faradic efficiency. The as-synthesized electrode displayed a high and stable STH conversion efficiency (19.8%) when employed for a solar-driven water electrolysis cell. This work paves the way for a new and promising strategy to prepare highly efficient and durable bifunctional electrocatalysts for a large-scale solar-to-hydrogen generation. coredata.dc:description: Designing cost-effective and high-efficiency electrocatalysts is critical to the water splitting performance during hydrogen generation. Herein, we have developed Fe2P-Co2P heterostructure nanowire arrays with excellent lattice torsions and grain boundaries for highly efficient water splitting. According to the microstructural investigations and theoretical calculations, the lattice torsion interface not only contributes to the exposure of more active sites but also effectively tunes the adsorption energy of hydrogen/oxygen intermediates via the accumulation of charge redistribution. As a result, the Fe2P-Co2P heterostructure nanowire array exhibits exceptional bifunctional catalytic activity with overpotentials of 65 and 198 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions, respectively. Moreover, the Fe2P-Co2P/NF-assembled electrolyzer can deliver 10 mA cm−2 at an ultralow voltage of 1.51 V while resulting in a high solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency of 19.8% in the solar-driven water electrolysis cell.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences.
coredata.dc:title: Heterostructured bimetallic phosphide nanowire arrays with lattice-torsion interfaces for efficient overall water splitting
